Retrieved June 27, 2016]</ref><ref>[https://www.churchofengland.org/media/1891063/pilling_report_gs_1929_web.pdf ''Report of the House of Bishops Working Group on human sexuality''], 2013, 149, 151. Retrieved June 27, 2016.</ref> Also, in 2013, some in the Church of England planned a [[Liturgy|liturgical]] [[Blessing of same-sex unions in Christian churches|blessing of gay couples]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/politics/religion/2013/11/28/church-england-plans-blessings-gay-couples|title=Church of England Plans Blessings for Gay Couples|work=advocate.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-religion-samesex/church-of-england-proposes-celebrating-gay-marriage-idUKBRE9AR0CP20131128|title=Church of England proposes celebrating gay marriage|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.K.|access-date=2017-10-01|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In January 2014, the College of Bishops<ref>[https://www.churchofengland.org/about-us/structure/general-synod/about-general-synod/house-of-bishops.aspx College of Bishops. Retrieved July 28, 2016. "All serving bishops in the Church of England comprise a body known as the College of Bishops"]</ref> endorsed the Pilling Report recommendation about process of conversations on the issue of homosexuality.<ref>[https://www.churchofengland.org/media/2015811/gs%20misc%201083%20-%20shared%20conversations%20on%20sexuality,%20scripture%20and%20mission.pdf College of Bishops Endorse Pilling Report’s Recommendations]. Retrieved June 27, 2016.</ref>
After the legalisation of same-sex marriages, the Church of England communicated that "the option of civil partnership should remain open for same-sex couples."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/church.of.england.says.civil.partnerships.should.not.be.abolished.following.gay.marriage.legalisation/36731.htm|title=Church of England says civil partnerships should not be abolished following gay marriage legalisation {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-10-30}}</ref>
In February 2014, the [[House of Bishops]] decreed the following:<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-26206192 No Gay Couple Blessings, 15 February 2014]</ref> * No special services of blessing for married same-sex couples, but allowed "more informal kinds of prayer, at the request of the couple [but this should] be accompanied by pastoral discussion of the Church's teaching and [the couple's] reasons for departing from it." * Clergy will not be allowed to enter same-sex marriages. * Clergy of the same sex are allowed by the Church to enter civil partnerships, but only on the understanding that they will remain celibate.
Still, "gay couples who get married will be able to ask for special prayers in the Church of England after their wedding, the bishops have agreed".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/10640144/Church-offers-prayers-after-same-sex-weddings-but-bans-gay-priests-from-marrying.html|title=Church offers prayers after same-sex weddings - but bans gay priests from marrying|access-date=2016-09-05}}</ref> As such, some congregations have offered "Prayers for a Same Sex Commitment".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stmaryandstnicolas.org.uk/prayerssame.html|title=St Mary and St Nicolas - Prayers for Same Sex Couples|last=Bennett|first=John|website=www.stmaryandstnicolas.org.uk|access-date=2016-09-05}}</ref> Moreover, "Bishops have little power to prevent gay clergy from marrying nor to sack them if they do. A panel of three senior bishops has been set up to advise other bishops on how to apply the guidance when clergy dissent. The usual format is an informal letter of rebuke and no further action, meaning more and more clergy are choosing to marry their same-sex partners."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/another.gay.anglican.priest.marries.long.term.partner/92022.htm|title=Another gay Anglican priest marries long-term partner {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-12-24}}</ref>
In April 2014, the Archbishop's Council and House of Bishops asked that the government to continue to offer civil partnerships saying that "The Church of England recognises that same-sex relationships often embody fidelity and mutuality ... Civil partnerships enable these Christian virtues to be recognised socially and legally in a proper framework."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/church.of.england.says.civil.partnerships.should.not.be.abolished.following.gay.marriage.legalisation/36731.htm|title=Church of England says civil partnerships should not be abolished following gay marriage legalisation {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-11-21}}</ref>
In September 2014, the College of Bishops met for three days. “Two of the days were devoted to the first of a series of shared conversations in the Church of England on Sexuality, Scripture and Mission. As part of the conversations the college shared the different responses being expressed in the life of the church and the deeply held convictions and experiences that inform them.”<ref>[https://www.churchofengland.org/media-centre/news/2014/09/college-of-bishops-meeting.aspx College of Bishops Meeting], 17 September 2014. Retrieved July 28, 2016.</ref> Also in September 2014, the Bishop of Leicester confirmed that a service of thanksgiving for a same-sex civil partnership "does not contravene any Church of England rules.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2014/09/17/bishop-and-archdeacon-back-gay-priest-in-commitment-ceremony-row/|title=Bishop and Archdeacon back gay priest in commitment ceremony row|work=PinkNews|access-date=2017-04-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/archdeacon-speaks-unholy-row-priest-s-service/story-22937990-detail/story.html|title=Archdeacon speaks out in unholy row over priest's service for his civil partnership|date=2014-09-17|work=Leicester Mercury|access-date=2017-05-19|language=en}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The Revd Andrew Cain, of St Mary's Church, [[Kilburn, London|Kilburn]] and St James' Church West, in [[North London]] planned to defy the House of Bishops' ban and bless same-sex marriages,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-26741447|title=London's Rev Andrew Cain to defy same-sex blessings ban|work=BBC News}}</ref> as did a few others.<ref name="Brown27/03/2014"/> Weighing in on the issue, the Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, avoided taking a position on blessing same-sex marriages but did endorse civil gay marriages and prayer ceremonies to mark the important occasion for same-sex couples.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Swinfird|first1=Steven|title=Archbishop of Canterbury: I would attend my children's same-sex marriage if they were gay|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/12043688/Archbishop-of-Canterbury-I-would-attend-my-childrens-same-sex-marriage-if-they-were-gay.html|website=telegraph.co.uk|publisher=Telegraph UK|accessdate=January 2, 2016}}</ref> Some congregations and clergy, as allowed by the permission for "informal kinds of prayer", such as St John's Church in Waterloo in South London, have begun to invite same-sex couples to receive "services of thanksgiving following a civil marriage ceremony".<ref>{{cite web|title=Weddings|url=offer services of thanksgiving following a civil marriage ceremony.|website=stjohnswaterloo.org|publisher=St John's at Waterloo|accessdate=April 12, 2016}}</ref> Same-sex attracted people who are ordained [[deacon#Anglicanism|deacons]], [[priest#Anglican or Episcopalian|priests]] and [[bishop]]s are forbidden to [[Marriage|marry]] someone of the same sex and [[Sexual orientation|same-sex attracted]] people who are married to someone of the same sex are forbidden to be [[Minister (Christianity)|ordained]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-26206192|title=Gay couple blessings ruled out by Church of England bishops|work=BBC News}}</ref> [[Ben Bradshaw]] [[Member of Parliament#United Kingdom|MP]] wanted the position of the Church of England clarified. Specifically, he demanded to know if Church of England [[clergy]] who married a same-sex partner would be disciplined or [[Defrocking#Anglicanism|defrocked]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-26759470|title=MP urges Church of England clarity on same-sex marriage priests|work=BBC News}}</ref> Gay people, including those in same-sex [[Civil partnership in the United Kingdom|civil partnership]]s or [[Same-sex marriage|marriages]], are allowed to become clerics but are expected to remain [[Celibacy|celibate]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jan/20/church-england-accept-gay-clergy|title=Church of England 'must accept actively gay clergy'|author=David Shariatmadari|work=the Guardian}}</ref> ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' wrote in a 2014 article that [[Ordination of LGBT Christian clergy|gay clergy]] who enter into same-sex marriage or bless same-sex marriages risk being defrocked and losing their jobs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/02/15/church-of-england-gay-marriage_n_4793630.html|title=Church Of England Clergy Could Be Defrocked If They Marry Gay Partner|work=The Huffington Post UK}}</ref> Seven clerics planned to marry regardless, defying their bishops.<ref name="Brown27/03/2014">[https://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/mar/27/archbishop-of-canterbury-signal-end-c-of-e-resistance-gay-marriage Archbishop of Canterbury signals end of C of E's resistance to gay marriage]</ref> Some Church of England bishops, however, fully accept and embrace gay clergy with partners or spouses in their diocese while other bishops remove the licences of such clergy, making it extremely difficult for them to find a position in another diocese.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://changingattitude.org.uk/campaigns/equality-for-lgbt-clergy-and-ordinands|title=LGBT ministers and clergy|work=changingattitude.org.uk|access-date=28 March 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110412055551/http://changingattitude.org.uk/campaigns/equality-for-lgbt-clergy-and-ordinands|archive-date=12 April 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2014, Canon Jeremy Pemberton married Laurence Cunnington, thus becoming the first priest in the Church of England to defy the church's ban on the marriage of gay clergy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/10762940/Church-of-England-faces-crisis-as-gay-priest-weds.html|title=Church of England faces 'crisis’ as gay priest weds|date=12 April 2014|work=Telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> Also in 2014, an openly lesbian and trans priest was appointed as a minor canon in Manchester Cathedral.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/transgender.priest.made.minor.canon.at.manchester.cathedral/37934.htm|title=Transgender priest Rachel Mann made minor canon at Manchester Cathedral: 'God did not reject me,' she says {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-04-30}}</ref>
In 2015, the Most Reverend [[John Sentamu]], [[Archbishop of York]], told a [[lay preacher]], Jeremy Timm, that if he persisted with plans to marry his long-time partner, his licence to [[Preacher|preach]] in Anglican churches would be revoked. As of August 2015, an agreement was reached: Timm would complete existing preaching commitments before revocation. Timm announced his plans to be married in September 2015 and to leave the Church of England<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/11796568/Gay-Anglican-preacher-forced-to-choose-between-marriage-or-ministry.html|title=Gay Anglican preacher forced to ‘choose between marriage or ministry’|date=11 August 2015|work=Telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> and join "Contemplative Fire", a dispersed, diverse and inclusive group that is primarily Anglican.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/anglican.preacher.quits.cofe.over.gay.marriage/61878.htm|title=Anglican preacher quits CofE over gay marriage - Christian News on Christian Today|work=christiantoday.com}}</ref><ref>[http://www.contemplativefire.org/guide.htm A Guide for the Contemplative Fire Community] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930180327/http://www.contemplativefire.org/guide.htm |date=30 September 2015 }} This group accepts people from other faith or non-faith backgrounds.</ref>
Other bishops and dioceses have supported same-gender marriage and have advocated for the right of gay priests to marry. For example, the Rt Revd Nick Holtam, the Bishop of [[Diocese of Salisbury|Salisbury]], endorsed same-sex marriage following its passage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/mar/28/gay-marriage-bishop-salisbury-backs-same-sex-weddings|title=Gay marriage: bishop of Salisbury gives backing to same-sex weddings|last=Brown|first=Andrew|date=2014-03-28|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref> In December 2015, the bishop of Buckingham announced his support for same-gender marriage within the church.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Church of England should be made to allow gay clergy to marry - bishop|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/11526563/Let-gay-clergy-marry-says-Church-of-England-bishop.html|website = Telegraph.co.uk|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> In 2016, another priest, in the [[Anglican Diocese of Southwark|Diocese of Southwark]], converted his civil partnership into marriage and "has kept his position".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/11927453/Married-gay-priest-elected-to-Church-of-England-Synod.html|title=Married gay priest elected to Church of England Synod|access-date=2016-08-04}}</ref> The ''[[Church Times]]'' also reported that St. Agnes in North Riddish held a "service of blessing" and "ceremony of commitment" for a priest who had resigned to marry his partner.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.churchtimes.co.uk/articles/2016/29-july/news/uk/priest-resigns-then-marries-gay-partner|title=Priest resigns then marries gay partner|website=www.churchtimes.co.uk|access-date=2018-01-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2016/07/24/gay-priest-quits-church-of-england-in-order-to-marry-his-partner/|title=Gay Priest quits Church of England in order to marry his partner|work=PinkNews|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-US}}</ref> The [[Diocese in Europe]] also reported the marriage of a same-gender couple that took place in a Lutheran church in Denmark calling a "truly joyful occasion".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://europe.anglican.org/news/news/post/1127-long-standing-synod-member-benefits-from-a-porvoo-partnership-|title=LONG STANDING SYNOD MEMBER BENEFITS FROM A PORVOO PARTNERSHIP - News - Diocese in Europe|website=europe.anglican.org|access-date=2016-08-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160821090722/http://europe.anglican.org/news/news/post/1127-long-standing-synod-member-benefits-from-a-porvoo-partnership-|archivedate=21 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[Diocese of Chichester]] featured Gay Pride in Brighton and encouraged participation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chichester.anglican.org/news/2016/08/02/pride-teaparty-brighton-church/|title=Brighton churches embrace UK's biggest Pride Festival - Diocese of Chichester|last=Ltd|first=Diocese of Chichester vs Blanc|website=www.chichester.anglican.org|access-date=2016-08-21}}</ref> Also, the [[Diocese of Lichfield|Diocese of Litchfield]] launched a congregation especially to reach out to LGBTI people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lichfield.anglican.org/ournews/new-lgbti-congregation-in-lichfield-diocese/|title=Diocese of Lichfield {{!}} New LGBTI congregation in Lichfield Diocese|last=Lichfield|first=Diocese of|website=www.lichfield.anglican.org|access-date=2016-08-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160821123911/http://www.lichfield.anglican.org/ournews/new-lgbti-congregation-in-lichfield-diocese/|archivedate=21 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The bishop of the [[Anglican Diocese of Liverpool|Diocese of Liverpool]] has called for the church to be more inclusive of same-gender relationships.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/16/senior-bishop-change-church-of-england-attitudes-gay-people|title=Senior bishop calls for change in C of E attitudes to gay people|last=correspondent|first=Harriet Sherwood Religion|date=2016-06-16|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-08-21}}</ref> In 2018, the [[Diocese of St Edmundsbury and Ipswich|Diocese of St. Edmundsbury and Ipswich]] appointed the Revd [[Joe Hawes]], who is in a civil partnership, as dean of the cathedral.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stedscathedral.co.uk/news/953-new-dean-for-st-edmundsbury-cathedral|title=St Edmundsbury Cathedral - A New Dean|last=acc|first=Chris Nicholls - new|website=www.stedscathedral.co.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-03-18}}</ref> Later, the Anglican [[Diocese of Lichfield]] communicated support for "radical Christian inclusion" and that churches should welcome and honour LGBTI people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lichfield.anglican.org/news/2018/05/09/welcoming-and-honouring-lgbt-people/|title=Diocese of Lichfield - News - Welcoming and honouring LGBT+ people|last=Lichfield|first=Diocese of|website=www.lichfield.anglican.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref>
In 2016, the General Synod announced that, in response to the growing support for gay marriage, it will reconsider allowing blessing rites for same-gender couples entering into marriage.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Church of England's centuries-old teaching on marriage 'up for discussion' to accommodate same-sex couples|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/12159981/Church-of-Englands-centuries-old-teaching-on-marriage-up-for-discussion.html?fb_ref=Default|website = Telegraph.co.uk|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> Additionally, an openly married gay priest was elected to the 2016 General Synod representing a historic moment for gay rights in the church.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bingham|first1=John|title=Married gay priest selected to Church of England Synod|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/11927453/Married-gay-priest-elected-to-Church-of-England-Synod.html|website=telegraph.co.uk|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=April 17, 2016}}</ref>
From 10 to 12 July 2016, following the prorogation of the meeting of the General Synod, most "members met in an informal setting in which they listened and were heard as they reflected together on scripture and a changing culture in relation to their understanding of human sexuality".<ref>[http://www.bristol.anglican.org/2016/statement-following-conclusion-of-shared-conversations-process/ General Synod Shared Conversation 10-12 July 2016. Retrieved July 27, 2016.]</ref>
The Church of England’s official Statement after the synod's members completed their informal reflections said that "the Shared Conversations over the last two years now come to a conclusion with over 1300 members of the church directly involved. It is our hope that what has been learned through the relationships developed will inform the way the church conducts whatever further formal discussions may be necessary in the future. It is our prayer that the manner in which we express our different views and deep disagreements will bear witness to Jesus who calls us to love as he has loved us."<ref>[https://www.churchofengland.org/media-centre/news/2016/07/statement-following-conclusion-of-shared-conversations-process.aspx Conclusion of Shared Conversations Process], Retrieved July 27, 2016.</ref>
In September 2016, the Bishop of Grantham, the [[Nicholas Chamberlain|Rt Rev Nicholas Chamberlain]], announced that he is gay and in a celibate relationship with his male partner becoming the first bishop to do so in the Anglican church.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/02/nicholas-chamberlain-bishop-of-grantham-c-of-e-gay-relationship|title=Bishop of Grantham first C of E bishop to declare he is in gay relationship|last=correspondent|first=Harriet Sherwood Religion|date=2016-09-02|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-09-02}}</ref> Following, Bishop Nicholas' 'coming out', he "received high-level support from the most senior official in the Anglican communion" as the Secretary General, Dr Josiah Idowu-Fearon, said that "the Anglican Communion has never made sexual orientation a condition of eligibility to hold office within the church and I reject the suggestion that it has".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/top.anglican.official.backs.bishop.of.grantham.over.sexuality/94779.htm|title=Top Anglican official backs Bishop of Grantham over sexuality {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-09-06}}</ref>
In November, 2016, William Nye, the Secretary General of the Archbishop's Council, confirmed the following:<ref name=":7" /> * clergy in the Church of England are indeed permitted to enter into civil partnerships (which are legally not the same as marriage, and therefore have no bearing on the doctrine of marriage); * clergy in the Church of England are permitted to offer prayers of support on a pastoral basis for people in same-sex relationships; * churches are able to indicate that they welcome LGBTI people, just as they would welcome all people; * clergy and laity are entitled to argue for changes to teaching and practice. On January 15, 2017, Bishop [[Rachel Treweek]], the bishop for the [[Diocese of Gloucester]] and first diocesan woman bishop, presided over an "LGBT Eucharist" sponsored by [[Inclusive Church]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/senior.anglican.bishop.to.preside.at.lgbt.eucharist/102037.htm|title=Senior Anglican Bishop To Preside At LGBT Eucharist {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-11-25}}</ref> During the General Synod of 2017, the House of Clergy voted against the motion to 'take note' of a conservative position on marriage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/church.of.englands.clergy.issue.shock.rebuke.to.bishops.conservative.view.on.sexuality/104738.htm|title=Church Of England's Clergy Issue Shock Rebuke To Bishops' View On Sexuality {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-17}}</ref> As a result of needing a majority in all three houses, the General Synod rejected the motion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/15/church-england-votes-reject-controversial-gay-marriage-report/|title=Church takes step towards gay marriage after vote rejects controversial report|newspaper=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-02-17|language=en-GB}}</ref> Following the rejection of the 'take note' motion, the Archbishops of Canterbury and York called for the need of a "radical new Christian inclusion" that is "founded in Scripture, in reason, in tradition, in theology and the Christian faith as the Church of England has received it; it must be based on good, healthy, flourishing relationships, and in a proper 21st century understanding of being human and of being sexual."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/archbishops.call.for.radical.new.christian.inclusion.after.synod.blocks.sexuality.report/104775.htm|title=Archbishops Call For 'Radical New Christian Inclusion' After Synod Blocks Sexuality Report {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-17}}</ref> In October 2017, the [[Diocese of Hereford]] voted in favour of a motion supporting liturgies for same-sex couples to dedicate a civil partnership or civil marriage in church; the General Synod is set to discuss the motion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-41701458|title=Church to discuss same-sex blessing|last=May|first=Callum|date=2017-10-20|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-10-22|language=en-GB}}</ref>
On February 12, 2018, the Church of England's Education Office published a policy supporting sex education which includes, among other things, education concerning one's sexual desire.<ref name=sexed>https://www.churchofengland.org/sites/default/files/2018-03/Relationships%20and%20Sex%20Education%20Response.pdf</ref> The policy stated that "Sex education should include an understanding that all humans are sexual beings and that sexual desire is natural. Pupils should be taught that humans express their sexuality differently and that there is diversity in sexual desire."<ref name=sexed />
===Church of Ireland=== {{Main|Church of Ireland}} Within the [[Church of Ireland]] there is a wide spectrum of opinion. In general, the church recognises four viewpoints ranging from opposition to acceptance of same-gender relationships.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ireland.anglican.org/information/85|title=Church of Ireland - A Member of the Anglican Communion|last=Synod)|first=Central Communications Board of the General|website=ireland.anglican.org|access-date=2016-05-15}}</ref> [[Christian fundamentalism|Conservatives]] expressed great concern about the blessing of the relationship of a lesbian couple in St. Nicolas' Collegiate Church, [[Galway]] in September 2002. The [[rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]] of the parish, the Reverend Patrick Towers, told the press, "I refuse to do weddings of same gender couples as they simply don't exist. But I am always very happy to look favourably on anyone seeking a blessing, be it for divorced couples, animals or friendships. It was a standard blessing, one I wrote myself, based on the [[Claddagh ring]] theme."<ref>Daily Mirror, 28 September 2002, [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-92208364.html Lesbian couple get church blessing]. Retrieved 24 January 2009.</ref> There was also widespread concern within the Church of Ireland at the [[Church of Ireland Bishop of Limerick|Bishop of Limerick]]'s attendance at [[Gene Robinson]]'s consecration.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.efic.org.uk/gene |title=The Consecration of V Gene Robinson as Bishop Coadjutor of New Hampshire in the Episcopal Church of the United States of America: A Statement from the Evangelical Fellowship of Irish Clergy|date=4 December 2003|publisher=Evangelical Fellowship of Irish Clergy|accessdate=1 March 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060809210936/http://www.efic.org.uk/gene |archivedate = 9 August 2006}}</ref><ref>Reform Ireland, 23 March 2004, [http://www.reform-ireland.org/article/219 The Creeping Acceptance of Same-sex Relationships in the Church of Ireland]. Retrieved 13 June 2007.</ref> Views at parish level reflect this, with many [[Evangelicalism|evangelical]] parishes as well as those in the more populous (in terms of Church of Ireland membership) north being generally opposed to LGBT identities, while [[Broad church|middle]] and [[high church]] parishes, especially in the south, have [[Coming out|openly]] gay parishioners as a matter of routine. For example, at General Synod 2005, Dean Michael Burrows (now a bishop) stated that he regularly gives [[Eucharist|Holy Communion]] to same-sex attracted parishioners in long-standing relationships.<ref>''Irish Angle'', 31 March 2006, [http://irishangle.net/nuacht/node/358 Michael Burrows goes to Cashel] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928150558/http://irishangle.net/nuacht/node/358 |date=28 September 2007 }}. Retrieved 13 June 2007.</ref> Moreover, many of the church's congregations, including seven cathedrals, are publicly and officially affirming of same-sex couples.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://changingattitudeireland.org/welcoming-and-open-congregations-in-ireland/other-churches-supportive-of-lgbt-christians/|title=Other Churches supportive of LGBT Christians|website=Changing Attitude Ireland|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-25}}</ref>
The bishops have announced a process of listening and reflection within the church. A preliminary response to the [[Windsor Report]] was produced by the church's standing committee in January 2005. Most of the northern dioceses passed motions favouring the [[Lambeth Conference]]'s Resolution I.10, although a similar motion failed to receive overall endorsement in the Diocese of Connor, covering most of [[County Antrim]] and the diocese with the most members in the Church of Ireland.<ref>''Irish Angle'', 27 December 2004, [http://www.irishangle.net/nuacht/?q=node/229 "Mapping Attitudes to Sexuality"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928150505/http://www.irishangle.net/nuacht/?q=node%2F229 |date=28 September 2007 }}. Retrieved 22 March 2007.</ref> Then, in 2010, the denomination recognised that a congregation within the church had received the 'Straight-up' Rebel award, an LGBT award, for its special services for LGBTI people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ireland.anglican.org/news/3278|title=Church of Ireland - A Member of the Anglican Communion|last=Synod)|first=Central Communications Board of the General|website=ireland.anglican.org|access-date=2016-04-30}}</ref>
[[Civil partnership in the United Kingdom|Civil Partnerships]] have been allowed since 2005. "The Church of Ireland has not taken a formal stance on the issue" of civil unions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-14787854|title=Minister Rev Tom Gordon partnership 'welcomed'|website=bbc.com|publisher=BBC|accessdate=January 11, 2016}}</ref> In 2008, "the Church of Ireland Pensions Board has confirmed that it will treat civil partners the same as spouses."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/listening-process-vital-to-bring-gay-lesbian-clergy-in-from-margins-1.945021|title=Listening process vital to bring gay, lesbian clergy in from margins|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2017-05-26|language=en-US}}</ref> In 2011, a senior priest in the Church of Ireland entered into a same-sex civil partnership and the relationship was celebrated by his community.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.portadowntimes.co.uk/news/my-same-sex-union-has-been-accepted-by-the-church-says-cleric-1-3039807|title=My same-sex union has been accepted by the church says cleric|last=|first=|date=September 10, 2011|website=portadowntimes.org.co.uk|publisher=Portadown Times|access-date=December 5, 2016}}</ref> Unlike the Church of England, clergy entered into a civil union "without being asked for any assurances regarding lifestyle."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.coigazette.net/coi-gazette-5th-june-2015/|title=COI Gazette – 5th June 2015|date=2015-06-05|newspaper=Church of Ireland Gazette|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160325155349/http://www.coigazette.net/coi-gazette-5th-june-2015/|archivedate=25 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Since then, other priests have been taking the time and opportunity to come out about their experiences. In 2012, the church's Clergy Pension Fund recognised that "the pension entitlement of a member’s registered civil partner will be the same as that of a surviving spouse."<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ireland.anglican.org/cmsfiles/pdf/AboutUs/cpf/CPF_Booklet_12.pdf|title=Church of Ireland: Clergy Pension Fund Explanatory Booklet|last=|first=|date=April 2012|website=ireland.anglican.org|publisher=Church of Ireland|access-date=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
In 2015, the [[Bishop of Cork]], [[Paul Colton]], announced his support of same-sex marriage, becoming the first Church of Ireland bishop to do so, saying that "The events in society are moving very rapidly and the church is not at all up to pace with the debate."<ref>{{Cite web|title = Same-sex marriage backed by Church of Ireland bishop - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-27460784|accessdate = 2015-10-06}}</ref> Following Bishop Colton, two retired archbishops of Dublin also voiced their 'yes' vote in favour of same-sex marriages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/religion-and-beliefs/archbishops-and-leading-theologian-call-for-yes-vote-1.2210129|title=Archbishops and leading theologian call for Yes vote|website=The Irish Times|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-25}}</ref> The [[Bishop of Cashel and Ossory]], [[Michael Burrows (bishop)|Michael Burrows]], also endorsed same-sex marriage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/vote2015/2015/0523/703227-same-sex-marriage-referendum-no-reaction/|title=Church needs to do a reality check - Archbishop|date=2015-05-23|newspaper=RTE.ie|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref> While opposing gay marriage, Bishop Pat Storey, Ireland's first woman bishop, did endorse and express support for same-sex civil unions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legacy.wtsp.com/story/news/2015/05/22/ireland-gay-marriage-public-vote/27766901/|title=Ireland set to approve gay marriage in public vote|website=10NEWS|access-date=2016-04-12}}</ref> On May 23, 2015, the people of [[Republic of Ireland]] voted in favour of the legalisation of same-sex marriage, the first country to do such by [[Election|popular vote]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Ireland becomes first country to legalise gay marriage by popular vote|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/23/gay-marriage-ireland-yes-vote|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-10-06|first = Henry McDonald in|last = Dublin}}</ref> In 2016, the Church of Ireland released a pastoral letter offering guidelines on same-gender marriage. Although the Church of Ireland does not currently offer marriage or blessing rites, the guidelines allow priests to offer pastoral prayers on behalf of the newly married couples.<ref>{{cite web|title=C of I bishops send pastoral letter to clergy on same-sex marriage|url=http://www.churchnewsireland.org/wp-content/uploads/CNI-News-Focus-January-1.pdf|website=churchnewsireland.org|publisher=Church of Ireland|accessdate=January 3, 2016}}</ref> Services of Thanksgiving for same-sex marriage have been hosted by congregations; for example, St. Audoen's Church hosted "a service of thanksgiving" for same-sex marriage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.churchnewsireland.org/wp-content/uploads/CNI-News-July-4.pdf|title=Church News Ireland: Service of Thanksgiving for referendum decision|last=|first=|date=July 2, 2015|work=|access-date=December 18, 2016|via=churchnewsireland.org}}</ref> REFORM Ireland, a conservative lobby within the Church of Ireland, has rejected the contents of the letter saying it is “a dangerous departure from confessing Anglicanism.”<ref>{{cite web|title=REFORM Ireland's Response to Bishops' Pastoral Letter on Same Sex Marriage|url=http://www.churchnewsireland.org/wp-content/uploads/CNI-News-Focus-Jan-2.pdf|website=churchnewsireland.org|publisher=REFORM Ireland|accessdate=January 3, 2016}}</ref>
Most recently, in 2016, many clergy in the Church of Ireland signed a letter supporting the U.S Episcopal Church and its open stance toward blessing same-sex couples.<ref>{{cite web|title=Letter from Church of Ireland clergy in support of TEC following Primates gathering|url=http://www.episcopalcafe.com/letter-from-church-of-ireland-clergy-in-support-of-tec-following-primates-gathering/|website=episcopalcafe.com|publisher=Episcopal Cafe|accessdate=February 1, 2016}}</ref> In January 2016, the ''Church of Ireland Gazette'', which is "editorially independent of the denomination", endorsed and supported a blessing rite for same-sex marriages in the church.<ref>{{cite web|title=Church of Ireland Gazette calls for blessings for same-sex marriages|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/northern-ireland-news/church-of-ireland-gazette-calls-for-blessings-for-same-sex-marriages-1-7184978|website=newsletter.co.uk|publisher=Newsletter UK|accessdate=April 17, 2016}}</ref> A church report has also said "the moral logic underpinning the negative portrayal of same-sex eroticism in Scripture does not directly address committed, loving, consecrated same-sex relationships today."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/church.of.ireland.challenged.by.report.on.homosexuality/77080.htm|title=Church of Ireland challenged by report on homosexuality {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-05-14}}</ref> In 2017, the General Synod considered a motion to request public services of thanksgiving for same-sex relationships; the vote was 176 against the motion, 146 in favour, and 24 abstained.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/church-of-ireland-faces-northsouth-divide-over-gay-marriage-stance-35686003.html|title=Church of Ireland faces north-south divide over gay marriage stance - BelfastTelegraph.co.uk|work=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-05-25|language=en}}</ref> The General Synod also unanimously accepted a report from the church's select committee on human sexuality recommending "that the Bishops further examine the unresolved theological differences as represented in the select committee, with a view to making proposals to facilitate a way forward."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ireland.anglican.org/news/7154/report-of-select-committee-on|title=Report of Select Committee on Human Sexuality Urges Bishops to Carry on the Conversation|work=Church of Ireland|access-date=2017-05-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/uk/belfast-telegraph/20170506/281479276323960|title=PressReader.com - Connecting People Through News|website=www.pressreader.com|access-date=2017-05-25}}</ref> The Bishop of Cork, Paul Colton, announced his support for the introduction of same-sex marriage in the Church of Ireland.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/cork-bishop-calls-for-same-sex-marriages-in-church-of-ireland-793217.html|title=Cork bishop calls for same-sex marriages in Church of Ireland|date=2017-06-12|access-date=2017-06-19}}</ref>
In 2018, the Irish bishops released a statement on the continuing conversations surrounding human sexuality. The Bishops stated that the church's teaching is that marriage is between a man and a woman, but acknowledged that they are divided on the subject themselves. The letter says that clergy cannot perform or bless a same-sex marriage, but that clergy can offer prayers for a couple who have married in a civil ceremony.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/church-of-ireland-stance-on-samesex-marriage-unchanged-36898595.html|title=Church of Ireland stance on same-sex marriage 'unchanged'|work=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk|access-date=2018-05-20|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> The liberal wing wanting change noted that "the statement allows for autonomy at a diocesan and parish level, for prayer and pastoral celebration with LGBT+ couples who have married, although this is not by means of solemnization, formal blessing or specifically sanctioned liturgy."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://changingattitudeireland.org/news-blog/statement-from-changing-attitude-ireland-on-the-recent-communication-from-the-house-of-bishops/|title=Statement from Changing Attitude Ireland on the Recent Communication from the House of Bishops|website=changingattitudeireland.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-05-20}}</ref>
===Church in Wales=== {{Main|Church in Wales}}
The [[Church in Wales]] currently has clergy and lay members with differing views regarding the subject of human sexuality. However, the trend has been for the church to move in a more liberal direction. The Church in Wales has taken steps toward allowing same-sex marriages and blessing rites for same-sex unions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.premier.org.uk/News/UK/Church-in-Wales-to-consider-allowing-gay-marriage|title=Church in Wales to consider allowing gay marriage - Premier|last=Premier|date=2018-09-13|work=Premier|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en-GB}}</ref> After the Welsh bishops released a statement declaring it "unjust" to not provide formal provisions for same-sex marriages and civil partnerships, the General Synod voted in favour of requesting such formal rites for same-sex relationships.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-wales-45503615|title=Provision explored for same sex couples|date=2018-09-12|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In 2011, the Church in Wales allowed priests in civil partnerships to receive full employee benefits.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/church-wales-looks-pension-rights-1811046 |title=Church in Wales looks at pension rights for clerics’ partners. |website=walesonline |access-date=2016-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304160958/http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/church-wales-looks-pension-rights-1811046 |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }}</ref> In 2012, the Archbishop of Wales, Barry Morgan, endorsed civil marriage for same-sex couples and encouraged other Anglicans to support the legislation.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Taylor|first1=Jerome|title=Archbishop of Wales publicly calls on Anglican stop support gay civil marriages|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/archbishop-of-wales-publicly-calls-on-anglicans-to-support-gay-civil-marriages-7657820.html|website=Independent.co.uk|publisher=Independent UK|accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref> After the archbishop offered his support for the civil policy, some bishops and dioceses developed legislation to alter the official position of the Church in Wales. The church has also endorsed an LGBT film meant to encourage support and affirmation for LGBT people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/church.in.wales.to.participate.in.lgbt.film.project/79862.htm|title=Church in Wales to participate in LGBT film project {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|website=www.christiantoday.com|access-date=2016-08-23}}</ref>
Since 2005, the Church in Wales has permitted priests to enter into same-sex [[Civil partnership in the United Kingdom|civil partnerships]]. “The Church in Wales has no formal view on whether people in civil partnerships who are in a sexual relationship can serve as clergy. If the issue arises, it is up to the relevant Bishop to decide.”<ref name=":2" />
In 2015, the governing body voted in favour of same-sex marriages, but a policy change requires further action. During the consultation and discussion, a majority of respondents voted in favour of same-gender marriage. Among the dioceses, the Diocese of St Asaph and the Diocese of Llandaff overwhelmingly supported same-sex marriage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Same-Sex Partnerships|url=http://cinw.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/13_02_SameSexPartnershipNote.pdf|website=churchinwales.org.uk|publisher=Governing Body|accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref> Overall, 52% of the Governing Body voted in favour of allowing same-sex marriages in church.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.churchtimes.co.uk/articles/2017/3-february/news/uk/the-welsh-church-is-now-a-more-welcoming-place|title=The Welsh Church is now a ‘more welcoming place’|website=www.churchtimes.co.uk|access-date=2017-10-08}}</ref> In April 2016, the Bench of Bishops decided to fully affirm same-sex couples and offer prayers of celebration for same-sex marriages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.livingchurch.org/unofficial-blessings-wales|title=Unofficial Blessings in Wales - The Living Church|website=www.livingchurch.org|access-date=2016-05-15}}</ref> Of the prayers provided for same-sex couples, Form One gives God thanks "for [the two people], who have found such love and companionship in each other, that it has led them to dedicate their lives in support of one another".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Prayers that may be said with a couple following the Celebration of Civil Partnership or Civil Marriage|last=|first=|publisher=Church in Wales|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=1}}</ref>
===Scottish Episcopal Church=== {{Main|Scottish Episcopal Church}}
The [[Scottish Episcopal Church]] (SEC) does not have a policy against [[Ordination|ordaining]] non-celibate gay clergy, thus such ordinations are theoretically allowed. They announced this on 23 March 2005: <blockquote> "[We] had never regarded the fact that someone was in a close relationship with a member of the same sex as in itself constituting a bar to the exercise of an ordained ministry ... We do not have a synodical decision like the Church of England has, which it made a number of years ago, and therefore if someone who was of a homosexual orientation felt a sense of call to the ordained ministry then we would begin the process of testing that vocation. We wouldn't bar him or her simply because they were homosexual."</blockquote>
Headlines in [[North America]] announced that the [[Scottish Episcopal Church]] had agreed to ordain gay and lesbian people in committed relationships. The Church thus released a statement pointing out that the policy was not news. Regarding the media release, the Church said: "Press interest has focused on one small part of the overall statement". It continued to say that: <blockquote> "In referring to the fact that there is no current bar to ordination for someone who might be in a close relationship with a member of the same sex, the Bishops were simply stating the present position as it applies in Scotland where, unlike some other provinces, no motion discouraging such ordinations has ever been passed by our General Synod. Consequently, the statement earlier this month does not represent any change in policy on the part of the Bishops."<ref>Thinking Anglicans: Book review archives, 24 March 2005.[http://www.thinkinganglicans.org.uk/archives/001085.html More on Scotland]. Retrieved 18 July 2007.</ref></blockquote>In 2005, clergy were able to enter into same-sex civil partnerships, and sexual abstinence is not a requirement in the Scottish Episcopal Church for such civil unions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lawandreligionuk.com/2014/12/15/scottish-bishops-on-marriage-and-civil-partnership/|title=Scottish Bishops on Marriage and Civil Partnership {{!}} Law & Religion UK|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> Since 2008, [[Glasgow Cathedral|St. Mary Cathedral in Glasgow]] has offered blessings for civil partnerships.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://weddings.thecathedral.org.uk/2011/04/02/same-sex-nuptials/|title=Same-Sex Nuptials|date=2011-04-02|website=Weddings at St Mary's Cathedral, Glasgow|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref>
In 2015, the Scottish Episcopal Church voted in favour of same-sex marriage ceremonies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.churchtimes.co.uk/articles/2015/12-june/news/uk/scottish-synod-opens-church-door-to-same-sex-weddings|title=Scottish Synod opens church door to same-sex weddings|website=www.churchtimes.co.uk|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref> Following that vote, the Dundee cathedral hosted its first same-sex wedding.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecourier.co.uk/news/local/dundee/dundee-cathedral-hosts-historic-same-sex-marriage-1.894036|title=Dundee cathedral hosts historic same-sex marriage|website=www.thecourier.co.uk|access-date=2016-04-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160412194318/http://www.thecourier.co.uk/news/local/dundee/dundee-cathedral-hosts-historic-same-sex-marriage-1.894036|archivedate=12 April 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2016, the General Synod voted in favour of amending the marriage canon to include same gender couples; the change required a second reading in 2017. The motion was approved by 97 votes to 33 with 3 abstensions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.anglicannews.org/news/2016/06/scottish-episcopal-church-takes-first-step-towards-same-sex-marriage.aspx|title=Scottish Episcopal Church takes first step towards same sex marriage|website=www.anglicannews.org|access-date=2016-06-10}}</ref>
After the Synod, Bishop [[David Chillingworth]], the Primus of the Scottish Episcopal Church, gave his assessment of the situation regarding the change in the marriage canon.<ref>[http://www.bishopdavid.net/2016/06/same-sex-marriage-where-are-we-now-pisky-anglican/ Chillingworth: Same-sex Marriage (June 24, 2016)] Retrieved 18 July 2016.</ref> In 2017, the General Synod approved the amendment to the marriage canon to include same-sex couples in the second reading.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-40190204|title=Scottish Episcopal Church approves gay marriage|date=2017-06-08|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en-GB}}</ref>
===Church of South India=== {{Main|Church of South India}}
The Church of South [[India]], although divided in opinion like many Anglican provinces, has many outspoken clergy in favour of rights for same-sex couples. "The Church of South India (CSI) [is] a relatively liberal Protestant church which has, since 1984, allowed women to become pastors. 'CSI has been liberal on these issues. It has taken up issues of gender, dalits and landlessness. It has to address the issue of sexual minorities too'."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/kerala-rising-cases-of-sexual-abuse-within-the-church/1/151572.html|title=Rising cases of sexual abuse within the church in Kerala force clergy to rethink on homosexuality|website=indiatoday.intoday.in|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref> In 2009, the Rev. Christopher Rajkumar, a presbyter in the Church of South India, stated that opposition to the rights of same-sex couples is a violation of human rights.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cithara|first1=Paul|title=Protestants support gay rights|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1090805/jsp/frontpage/story_11322140.jsp|website=telegraphindia.com|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=January 12, 2016}}</ref> Also in 2009, Bishop V. Devashayam supported legal rights for gay people saying "it is wrong to condemn people for their sexual orientation".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/Protestants+cool+with+verdict+on+homosexuality/1/54958.html|title=Protestants cool with verdict on homosexuality|access-date=2016-08-26}}</ref> Bishop Devashayam also argued that sexual orientation is genetic and that Scripture should be re-read from a contemporary context.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.christiantoday.co.in/article/church.urged.to.rethink.and.embrace.the.lgbt.community/4326.htm|title=Church pressed to rethink and embrace the LGBT community|last=Today|first=Christian|work=Christian Today|access-date=2018-01-29|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In 2015, [[St. Mark's Cathedral, Bangalore|St Mark's Cathedral in Bangalore]], a congregation of the CSI, hosted a forum on preventing homophobia, and the Rev. Vincent Rajkumar advocated for the support of gay rights.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sitlhou|first1=Makepeace|title=A Theological Challenge to Christian Homophobia|url=http://thewire.in/2015/12/09/a-theological-challenge-to-christian-homophobia-16685/|website=thewire.in|publisher=The Wire|accessdate=January 12, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151211203604/http://thewire.in/2015/12/09/a-theological-challenge-to-christian-homophobia-16685/|archivedate=11 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> CSI clergy, under the National Council of Churches in India, co-held a conference working against homophobia in Jakarta, Indonesia in 2014 featuring a rainbow flag and with speakers in favour of same-sex couples.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://josephgoh.org/?p=525|title=International Consultation on Church and Homophobia|date=2014-12-08|website=Joseph N. Goh|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-23}}</ref> Moreover, during the week of the Primates' meeting in Canterbury, the CSI was listed by the [[BBC]] as being among the Anglican provinces open to blessing same-sex couples.<ref>{{cite web|title=Church split over homosexuality would be a failure - Welby|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-35278124|website=bbc.com|publisher=BBC|accessdate=January 12, 2016}}</ref>
In 2016, a seminary affiliated with the CSI has begun offering a seminary on LGBT issues. "The [[Tamil Nadu Theological Seminary]] in Madurai held a two-hour seminar on gender and sexuality..."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thenewsminute.com/article/awesome-tamil-nadu-seminary-teaching-pastors-accept-lgbt-community-46577|title=Awesome! This Tamil Nadu seminary is teaching pastors to accept the LGBT community|date=2016-07-15|work=The News Minute|access-date=2017-12-11}}</ref>
===Church of the Province of South East Asia=== {{Main|Church of the Province of South East Asia}} ([[Cambodia]], [[Indonesia]], [[Laos]], [[Malaysia]], [[Nepal]], [[Singapore]], [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]])
The Province of South East Asia criticised the confirmation of [[Gene Robinson]] as a bishop by the [[Episcopal Church in the United States of America|Episcopal Church (USA)]], stating: <blockquote> "The said confirmation therefore seriously raises the question of ECUSA's genuine commitment to our corporate responsibility as members of the church catholic to uphold and promote only the Apostolic Faith and Order inherited. A natural, holistic and consistent reading of the Scriptures clearly show that it is against the practise of homosexuality. In the context of orthodox and classical Christianity, the canonical authority of the Scriptures is taken to be recognized and received by the community of faith and not subject to majority, culturally relevant or even theological voting."<ref>Diocese of Singapore, 13 August 2003. [http://www.anglican.org.sg/bishop_gene_robinson.html Statement of Bishops of the Province of the Anglican Church in South East Asia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060526161339/http://www.anglican.org.sg/bishop_gene_robinson.html |date=26 May 2006 }}. Retrieved 22 March 2007.</ref></blockquote>
On 24 November 2003, the province declared that it had entered into a state of impaired communion with the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]] by releasing the following statement: <blockquote> "The Synod of the Province of the Anglican Church of South East Asia unanimously rejects the purported consecration of Dr Gene Robinson on 2 November 2003 by the Episcopal Church in the United States of America, in New Hampshire, as a bishop in the Anglican Church. The Province views the purported consecration as a flagrant disregard of the fundamental teachings of the Bible and the long-established doctrines of the Church.</blockquote> <blockquote> As the Rev. Gene Robinson is a practising homosexual who had divorced his wife and has, for the last 13 years, been living with a male partner, the Province cannot and does not recognize his consecration and ministry in the Anglican church.</blockquote> <blockquote> In view of the ECUSA's action in proceeding with the consecration despite the warnings and pleas of a large majority of Anglican churches worldwide, the Province regrets that communion with the ECUSA as well as those who voted for the consecration and those who participated in the consecration service is now broken.</blockquote> <blockquote> This means that the Province no longer treats those in ECUSA who carried out and supported the act of consecration as brothers and sisters in Christ unless and until they repent of their action and return to embrace Biblical truths. At the same time, the Province remains in fellowship with the faithful believers within ECUSA who rightly oppose and reject the erroneous actions of their house.</blockquote> <blockquote> This decision was made unanimously at an extraordinary meeting of the Synod held in Kudat, Sabah, Malaysia, on 20 November 2003."<ref name="SEAsia_break" /></blockquote>
===Hong Kong Sheng Kung Hui (Hong Kong Anglican Church)=== {{Main|Hong Kong Sheng Kung Hui}} The fourth [[General Synod of Hong Kong Sheng Kung Hui|General Synod of the Hong Kong Sheng Kung Hui]], at its meeting on 15 October 2007, resolved that the Anglican Church in [[Hong Kong]] and [[Macau]] supports the recommendations contained in the [[Windsor Report]] so as to safeguard the unity of the [[Anglican Communion]]. However, Archbishop Peter Kwong, a former primate, stated that he supported diversity in the Communion saying "Anglicanism is inclusive ... so why shouldn't we find a common ground on homosexuality?".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.speroforum.com/a/7313/Hong-Kong-Anglican-leader-Dialogue-on-Sexuality#.V0LBPLQ-CT8|title=Hong Kong Anglican leader: Dialogue on Sexuality|website=www.speroforum.com|access-date=2016-05-23}}</ref> In 2013, some leaders in the Hong Kong Anglican Church endorsed civil rights legislation that provided legal protection for the LGBT community from discrimination.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Conger|first1=George|title=Hong Kong push for gay civil rights|url=https://geoconger.wordpress.com/2013/04/13/hong-kong-push-for-gay-civil-rights-the-church-of-england-newspaper-april-14-2013-p-7/|website=geoconger.wordpress.com|publisher=The Church of England Newspaper|accessdate=January 25, 2016}}</ref> Additionally, in 2015, the Rev. Peter Douglas Koon, the Anglican province's secretary general, objected to discrimination occurring in conservative schools and emphatically assured the LGBT community that Anglican schools would be accepting of LGBT faculty and students.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Conant|first1=Ariel|last2=So|first2=Melory|title=HK's closet mindset on LGBT issues|url=http://yp.scmp.com/news/features/article/99069/hks-closet-mindset-lgbt-issues|website=yp.scmp.com|publisher=youngpost|accessdate=January 25, 2016}}</ref>
=== Anglican Church in Aotearoa, New Zealand and Polynesia === {{Main|Anglican Church in Aotearoa, New Zealand and Polynesia}} There is no officially stated policy regarding homosexuality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/3226753.stm#newzealand|title=BBC NEWS - Special Reports - Anglican Church around the world|work=bbc.co.uk}}</ref> Members are also divided regarding agreement with the [[Windsor Report]] and [[Lambeth Conferences|Lambeth Conference]]. There is no single national approach toward the [[ordination]] of [[Coming out|openly]] [[Sexual orientation|gay]] or [[Ordination of LGBT Christian clergy|lesbian clergy]], although individual dioceses have supported or opposed the inclusion of LGBT clergy. However, in 2016, it has been announced that the church will go forward in provincially proposing the option of same-gender blessing rites.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Conger|first1=George|title=Gay marriage rites recommended for New Zealand church|url=http://www.anglican.ink/article/gay-marriage-rites-recommended-new-zealand-church|website=anglican.ink|publisher=Anglican Ink|accessdate=February 23, 2016}}</ref> In 2018, the Synod voted in favour of allowing blessing rites for same-sex marriages and civil unions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.anglicantaonga.org.nz/news/general_synod/yes|title=Anglican Taonga : New Zealand's Anglican News Leader|last=Quiqcorp|website=www.anglicantaonga.org.nz|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> Prior to official blessings, the church said that "clergy should be permitted 'to recognise in public worship' a same-gender civil union or state marriage of members of their faith community."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://anglicantaonga.org.nz/News/General-Synod/forward|title=Anglican Taonga : New Zealand's Anglican News Leader|last=Quiqcorp|website=anglicantaonga.org.nz|access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref>
Some [[Pākehā]] parishes are more open to gay and lesbian issues, including ordination and blessing of unions. The [[Dunedin]] and [[Auckland]] dioceses are notable for other such examples, including the ordination of a non-celibate gay clergy and the blessings of same-sex relationships performed by priests in an official capacity.<ref>Ashford, Ron,[http://www.duomo.ac.nz/RonAshfordsThesis.doc A Right to a Rite?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927142829/http://www.duomo.ac.nz/RonAshfordsThesis.doc |date=27 September 2007 }}, 2006.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gaynz.com/articles/publish/2/printer_3751.php|title=Anglican church to ordain gay deacon|website=www.gaynz.com|access-date=2016-05-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604064919/http://www.gaynz.com/articles/publish/2/printer_3751.php|archivedate=4 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the Dunedin Diocese, "Blessings of same-sex relationships are offered in line with Diocesan Policy and with the bishop's permission."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.saintmartinsnev.com/celebrations|title=St Martin's Anglican Church - NEV|website=St Martin's Anglican Church - NEV|access-date=2016-12-15}}</ref> In 2006, an openly gay and partnered deacon was ordained in the Dunedin Diocese.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10408968|title=Gay deacon a threat to church unity, say opponents|date=2006-11-03|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> Subsequently, the same deacon was ordained as a priest.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/79503/gay-priest-predicts-a-new-conservatism|title=Gay priest predicts a new conservatism {{!}} Otago Daily Times Online News : Otago, South Island, New Zealand & International News|website=www.odt.co.nz|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> The Diocese of Auckland has also established policies in favour of ordaining partnered gay and lesbian priests.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Coward|first1=Colin|title=Auckland Diocese Synod votes for full inclusion of lesbian and gay people in ministry|url=http://changingattitude.org.uk/archives/4354|website=changingattitude.org.uk|publisher=Changing Attitude|accessdate=January 31, 2016|archive-url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20171022000000/http://changingattitude.org.uk/archives/4354|archive-date=22 October 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> One priest, in a same-sex relationship, is an assistant priest in Auckland after being denied a licence in the Waikato Diocese.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/waikato-times/news/509074/Gay-minister-claims-discrimination|title=Gay minister claims discrimination|date=2008-06-27|work=Stuff.co.nz|access-date=2017-04-13|language=English}}</ref> Congregations may offer a 'relationship blessing' for two partners in the Auckland Diocese.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.saintcolumbas.org.nz/covenant.php|title=Saint Columba Church - Services|website=www.saintcolumbas.org.nz|access-date=2016-12-17}}</ref> In 2005, a same-sex couple was joined in a civil union at [[St Matthew's, Auckland|St. Matthew in the City]] in the Auckland Diocese.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/27677/civil-union-2005|title=Civil union, 2005|last=Taonga|first=New Zealand Ministry for Culture and Heritage Te Manatu|website=www.teara.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2017-04-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170413153151/http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/27677/civil-union-2005|archivedate=13 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2011, the Waiapu Diocese adopted a resolution affirming the ordination of gay and lesbian clergy and asking for an authorised liturgy for blessing same-sex relationships.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.waiapu.com/assets/Waiapu-SC-Ma-Whea-Submission.pdf|title=The Waiapu Journey|last=|first=|date=January 2013|website=waiapu.com|access-date=November 6, 2017}}</ref> The Bishop's chaplain in the Waiapu Diocese has also performed a blessing for a same-sex couple.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.baybuzz.co.nz/2013/07/08/gay-marriage-coming-to-the-bay/|title=Gay Marriage Coming to the Bay {{!}} BayBuzz|date=2013-07-08|work=BayBuzz|access-date=2017-11-08}}</ref> In 2017, the Bishop of [[Anglican Diocese of Waiapu|Waiapu]] installed an openly gay priest, who is married to his partner, as the Dean of [[Waiapu Cathedral of Saint John the Evangelist, Napier|Waiapu Cathedral]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gafcon.org/news/remaining-faithful-to-the-gospel-in-new-zealand-a-response-to-motion-29|title=Remaining faithful to the gospel in New Zealand - A response to Motion 29 {{!}} GAFCON|website=www.gafcon.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.anglicantaonga.org.nz/news/general_synod/tuesday|title=Anglican Taonga : New Zealand's Anglican News Leader|last=Quiqcorp|website=www.anglicantaonga.org.nz|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref>
New Zealand writer Liz Lightfoot has documented the experiences of individuals coming out in the Anglican Church as a contribution to the 'listening process' in the Anglican Church.<ref>Lightfoot, Liz, [http://www.otago.ac.nz/press/booksauthors/Outspoken_Coming_out_Church.html Outspoken], 2011.</ref>
In 2014, General Synod passes a resolution that would create a pathway towards the [[blessing]] of [[Sexual orientation|same-sex]] relationships, while upholding the [[Homophobia|traditional]] doctrine of marriage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://anglicantaonga.org.nz/News/General-Synod/forward|title=Anglican Taonga : New Zealand's Anglican News Leader|author=Quiqcorp|work=anglicantaonga.org.nz}}</ref> The synod in 2016 voted to receive the report on blessings but left the proposal to "[lie] on the table" and the report will be reviewed again in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gaynz.com/articles/publish/2/article_18259.php|title=GayNZ.com Anglican Church rejects blessings of same-sex marriages|website=www.gaynz.com|access-date=2016-05-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160512113658/http://www.gaynz.com/articles/publish/2/article_18259.php|archivedate=12 May 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://anglicantaonga.org.nz/News/General-Synod/BLESSINGS-REPORT-ON-HOLD|title=Anglican Taonga : New Zealand's Anglican News Leader|last=Quiqcorp|website=anglicantaonga.org.nz|access-date=2016-05-12}}</ref> "However, Synod did pass a constitutional change allowing bishops the right to authorize a service for use in his or her diocese."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.episcopalcafe.com/marriage-rites-and-wrongs/|title=Marriage rites (and wrongs)?|date=2016-08-30|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref> In 2018, General Synod/Te Hinota voted in favour of the process to approve Motion 29 and the blessing of same-sex relationships.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/home/new-zealand/2018/05/anglican-church-will-bless-same-sex-relationships.html|title=Anglican Church will bless same-sex relationships|work=Newshub|access-date=2018-05-09|language=en}}</ref>
===Anglican Church of Australia=== {{Main|Anglican Church of Australia}} In the Seventeenth Session of the General Synod of the Anglican Church of Australia in 2017, the synod passed a motion recognising "that the doctrine of our church, in line with traditional Christian teaching, is that marriage is an exclusive and lifelong union of a man and a woman, and further, recognises that this has been the subject of several General Synod resolutions over the past fifteen years".<ref>{{cite web|title=MINUTES OF THE FOURTH DAY OF THE SEVENTEENTH GENERAL SYNOD OF THE ANGLICAN CHURCH OF AUSTRALIA HELD IN SYNOD HALL, WANDINY ROOM, NOVOTEL TWIN WATERS RESORT, MAROOCHYDORE ON THURSDAY 7 SEPTEMBER 2017|url=https://www.anglican.org.au/data/GS17_Minutes_of_the_Day/General_Synod_-_Minutes_of_Day_4_2017_FINAL.pdf|publisher=Anglican Church of Australia|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref> In 2018, the Primate of Australia and Archbishop of Melbourne, [[Philip Freier]], released an ''ad clerum'' reiterating the current position that clergy cannot perform a same-sex marriage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/380705315/AD-Clerum-Changes-to-the-Marriage-Law#from_embed|title=AD Clerum Changes to the Marriage Law|website=Scribd|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.anglican.ink/article/no-sanctions-against-melbourne-gay-marriage-priests|title=No sanctions against Melbourne gay marriage priests|date=2018-06-01|work=Anglican Ink 2018 ©|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en}}</ref> At the same time, the church has "no official stance on homosexuality" itself.<ref name="factfile" />
At its 2004 general synod held in Perth, the church passed four resolutions on human sexuality. The key resolutions stated that, "Recognising that this is a matter of ongoing debate and conversation in this church and that we all have an obligation to listen to each other with respect, this General Synod does not condone the liturgical blessing of same sex relationships" and "this General Synod does not condone the ordination of people in open committed same sex relationships."<ref>Sydney Diocesan Secretariat, [http://www.sds.asn.au/site/100736.asp?ph=cl General Synod Session 2004]. Retrieved 8 August 2007.</ref> Nevertheless, the [[Anglican Diocese of Perth|Diocese of Perth]] has "a number of people in same-sex relationships amongst the clergy."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-10-29/anglican-reject/5052642|title=Archbishop rejects formal recognition of same-sex relationships|date=2013-10-29|newspaper=ABC News|language=en-AU|access-date=2016-12-10}}</ref> A former [[Primate (bishop)#Anglican Communion|primate]], [[Phillip Aspinall]], has stated that the topic is not worth splitting the church over.<ref name=factfile>BBC News, 13 February 2007. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/3226753.stm BBC Factfile: Anglican Church around the world]. Retrieved 18 July 2007.</ref> Archbishop Aspinall has also stated that he does not take an official position on the ordination of gay clergy, preferring instead to encourage respectful conversation.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Attard|first1=Monica|title=The Primate of the Anglican Church of Australia, Dr Phillip Aspinall|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2008/07/04/2294716.htm|website=abc.net.au|publisher=ABC|accessdate=April 11, 2016}}</ref> Another former primate, Archbishop Peter Carnley, stated that he believed "life-long gay relationships and commitments ... could receive church blessings."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucg.org/world-news-and-prophecy/in-brief-ordination-of-gay-priests-defining-issue-for-anglicans-in-australia|title=In Brief ...
